text: This is a tremendous accomplishment. It's not the end of ISIS the terror org, but it is the end of one of the most vicious, vile, and murderous regimes in the world. It's also bipartisan -- an offensive begun under Obama is concluded under Trump:
author: DavidAFrench

text:
It’s time for a total and complete shutdown of Hollywood until we can figure out what’s going on.

I mean . . . good lord.

text: San Antonio punishes Chick-fil-A for its donations to Christian organizations. Sorry, that's unconstitutional. It's also intolerant. And it's more fake outrage. Do people really not feel "welcome" if an airport has a Chick-fil-A?
author: DavidAFrench

text: Gardner-Webb is still up on Virginia? Someone do a health and wellness check on @RichLowry and @CaseyMattox_ !
author: DavidAFrench

text: After Trump's Golan decision, I've seen folks repeat the falsehood that Christians support Israel to hasten the apocalypse. No. Here are the real reasons why the vast bulk of Evangelicals support Israel, and they're good reasons indeed:
author: DavidAFrench

text: It is absolutely astounding. In hindsight, she's one of the great kingmakers in American politics. She lost leads against Obama and Trump, and she helped make Bernie a frontrunner.
author: DavidAFrench

text: It is amazing. She was trying to dunk on him.
author: DavidAFrench

text: My point is that absent the EC, the 2016 race would have been quite different. The fact that Hillary wasted money on an attempt to dunk on Trump with a resounding victory in both the EC and the popular vote doesn't change the fact that the EC impacted strategy from the start.
author: DavidAFrench

text: Yes, but there's a tremendous difference between trying to win the popular vote _in addition to_ the electoral college and trying to win the popular vote without regard to the electoral college. Those are different kinds of campaigns.
author: DavidAFrench

text: The point stands. The electoral college is a dominant factor in campaign strategy. Every campaign has its eyes fixed on the map, especially in close races. Absent the electoral college, GWB would have campaigned differently in 2004. Ohio would have been far, far less important.
author: DavidAFrench

text: I don't doubt you wanted to win the national popular vote after 2000, but in the absence of the electoral college, would GWB have made 15 stops in Ohio between October 1 and November 2, 2004? 18 stops in FL? http://p2004.org/bush/bushcal1004a.html …
author: DavidAFrench

text: I was playing Unreal when my wife went into labor with our first child. She said, "It will be very bad for our marriage if you don't stop playing . . . RIGHT NOW!"
author: DavidAFrench

text: Excellent piece from Eli.
author: DavidAFrench

text: One of the downsides of pro-life incrementalism is that it consistently gives the Court the pretext not to disturb the underlying holdings of Roe and Casey. Heartbeat bills are fundamentally incompatible with both. Pass them and challenge Roe:
author: DavidAFrench

text: Now is the time — in those states with pro-life majorities, it’s time to follow Iowa, Kentucky, and now Mississippi. Pass heartbeat bills. Bombard the Supreme Court with opportunities to overturn Roe. Enough incrementalism. Are we pro-life or less-death? https://www.nationalreview.com/2019/03/gop-legislatures-throw-down-the-gauntlet-pass-heartbeat-bills/ …
author: DavidAFrench

text: Unsurprising.
author: DavidAFrench

text: And you can post a longer list of good things about the man. I disagreed with many things he did. I appreciated many things he did. But decent people respect the fallen. Decent people acknowledge heroes. Trump isn’t decent.
author: DavidAFrench

text: Smug. No. Retract.
author: DavidAFrench

text: The disagreement in 2003 didn’t just boil down to WMD or 9/11. There were intense good-faith debates about justifications for _and_ the effects of the war. It was complex then and now. But much of the argument did deal with worries about what happened after Saddam was deposed.
author: DavidAFrench

text: It depends on the ideological composition of the 70 and the 30. The large state/small state divide is not the same as red/blue.
author: DavidAFrench

text: We don’t know what today would look like if we had let Saddam remain. I think worse is probable. You think better is likely. This explains much of the disagreement today, just as it did in 2003.
author: DavidAFrench

text: Saddam-led Iraq was an instrument of instability and aggression even after Desert Storm. He was “stable” only in the sense that he had control over most of his country.
author: DavidAFrench

text: As for Bush, I still agree with the decision to invade, but he and his commanders are responsible for the mistakes that contributed to the early success of the insurgency. I also think he corrected those mistakes (at great cost).
author: DavidAFrench

text: I believe Obama made a mistake when he didn’t push harder for a SOFA. But it’s to his credit that he intervened to save Iraq from possible dissolution then launched offensives into Syria and Iraq to defeat the caliphate. He laid the groundwork for the present military success.
author: DavidAFrench

text: Would you classify the inability to negotiate a new SOFA as a failure, in hindsight? Do you think the admin should have pushed harder for an agreement? Or that withdrawal was the right call? I presume you supported re-entry to fight ISIS.
author: DavidAFrench

text: It's the 16th anniversary of the Iraq War, and Twitter is full of condemnations. I dissent. I thought the war was just and proper then. I think the same thing now:
author: DavidAFrench

text: Dear Trumpists who hate the GOP establishment because you completely wrongly think they never "won" anything or never resisted the Dems, there is no definition of political "fighting" that necessitates spitting on the grave of a dead war hero.
author: DavidAFrench

text: If anyone thinks the American republic would remain stable if political power is consolidated in coastal urban enclaves, then they lack understanding of American history, American culture, and human nature. A few thoughts on the electoral college:
author: DavidAFrench

text: Congrats @benshapiro it's an excellent book.
author: DavidAFrench

text: This is disgusting. The president's defenders frequently underestimate the malignant effect of such a toxic person on a nation and a political party.
author: DavidAFrench

text: Reality check: No rational candidate has ever run a race to win the national popular vote. It’s like playing a basketball game to shoot the most free throws. We don’t know who would have won in 2016 if the candidates tried to win on that basis: https://www.nationalreview.com/corner/theres-a-partisan-fiction-at-the-heart-of-the-case-against-the-electoral-college/ …
author: DavidAFrench

text:
Southern parents watching the higher ed admissions scandal: “Obsession with elite schools is weird.”

Same parents, facing a sports cheating scandal: “Second Amendment remedies!”
author: DavidAFrench

text:
This is your primary: Move to the left, pivot to the center for the general.

This is your primary on Twitter: Sprint to the the left -- advocate busting constitutional norms and transforming the economy -- and fatally undermine the chance to pivot?
author: DavidAFrench

text: End the electoral college? Sure! Break the legislative filibuster? Let's think on it. Pack the court? Good thought! End all private health insurance? Yes! How much is Twitter amplifying and intensifying the Democrats' sprint to the Left? https://www.nationalreview.com/2019/03/could-the-twitter-primary-cost-democrats-the-oval-office/ …
author: DavidAFrench

text: Nope! I believe @kdrum came up with it many years ago. It seems to be catching on a bit more now. It’s perfect, isn’t it?
author: DavidAFrench

text: Nutpicking radical professors is a sport on some quarters of the right. Find bad tweets, elevate the radical professor as a symbol of academia, and demand his ouster. It's a tired formula that undermines free speech:
author: DavidAFrench

text: I've read @benshapiro's new book, and it's outstanding, a necessary addition to the contemporary debate about the nature and value of the American experiment. Today is release day. Congrats Ben!
author: DavidAFrench

text: One of the more disturbing aspects of the Trump phenomenon is the way in which his movement has elevated reprehensible people.
author: DavidAFrench

text: So, when people on the left were calling for Tucker Carlson's head, there was an effort on the right to fire an obscure leftist UC Davis professor for his old tweets. Fake outrage machines are dangerous to free speech. Period. https://www.nationalreview.com/corner/fake-outrage-machine-right-radical-professors/ …
author: DavidAFrench

text: The Connecticut Supreme Court issued a ruling with extraordinary implications for the Second Amendment. Unless SCOTUS intervenes, gun manufacturers and sellers are under a new legal threat:
author: DavidAFrench

text: A terrible court ruling got lost in last weekend's news. The Connecticut Supreme Court defied federal law. Its ruling represents a direct threat the Second Amendment, and (for a bonus) it also implicates the First Amendment. SCOTUS must intervene: https://www.nationalreview.com/2019/03/sandy-hook-ruling-placed-firearms-industry-under-legal-threat/ …
author: DavidAFrench

text: Since an "assault weapons" ban is once again a topic at home and abroad, it's worth remembering how pointless the ban is as a matter of policy:

text: Nice job changing the subject. You said something clearly, demonstrably wrong about coverage of terror in the Anglosphere. If you started by lamenting lack of coverage of terror in the developing world I would have agreed with you. That wasn’t your argument. Don’t pretend it was.
author: DavidAFrench

text: He said New Zealand. As you know, jihadist terror in Europe and the Anglosphere is heavily-covered. Paris. Nice. Manchester. London.
author: DavidAFrench

text: As you well know, terror attacks in the Middle East and developing world are covered in western media far less, no matter the identity of the target. You said New Zealand, not Africa. Did we lack for coverage of the Paris attacks? Nice? Manchester?

author: DavidAFrench

text: In the world of mass shooters, both motive and method can have independent inspiring effects on evil minds. In New Zealand, the motive looks like far-right terrorism. I'm concerned, however, that the livestream method might resonate beyond those bounds:
author: DavidAFrench

text: I hope and pray that I'm wrong, but I fear the New Zealand shooter may have rewritten the mass-shooter script is a terrible way. Some dark thoughts, with no clear solution: https://www.nationalreview.com/2019/03/did-the-new-zealand-shooter-change-the-cultural-script/ …
author: DavidAFrench

text: I’ve read. It’s very interesting. Thanks.
author: DavidAFrench

text: Yes, that’s the point. Take great care. Instead, I see people reading to reinforce priors.
author: DavidAFrench

text: I don’t claim to be an expert in interpreting terrorist manifestos, but if you take seriously all those parts that reinforce your priors and ascribe the rest to “trolling” or “shitposting,” you might be doing it a tiny bit wrong.
author: DavidAFrench

text: Worth re-upping from yesterday:
author: DavidAFrench

text: “Accused of appearing to revel” is long, long, long way from “reveling.” The woke war on Beto will be something to behold.
author: DavidAFrench
